title: importing methods with rollup
body:
Is there something wrong with this ?

``` js
import cloneDeep   from 'lodash-es/lang/cloneDeep'
import merge       from 'lodash-es/obj/merge'
```

rollup is showing the following error.

```
/Users/ritz078/projects/embed.js/node_modules/lodash-es/internal/root.js: 'import' and 'export' may only appear at the top level (31:0)
```

rollup plugin config : 

``` js
plugins      : [
    npm({
        jsnext: true,
        main  : true
    }),
    commonjs({
        include: 'node_modules/**'
    }),
    babel()
]
```

title: add _ getter for value call for lodash v4+
body:
There is a very handful sugar to `chain` method when we could just wrap value in `_` call. Now, when `Lodash` finally drop support of IE 8 and IE 9 is supporting getters we could add symmetric sugar to `value` with adding getter `_` that is calling `value` on read and so unwrap would become as easy as wrap. Example:

```
let a = [{x: 1}, {x: 2}, {x: 3}]

_(a).map('x').takeWhile(v => v < 3).value() // was

_(a).map('x').takeWhile(v => v < 3)._       // become
```

title: Find if array includes all elements from another array
_.remove with undefined second argument truncates the array
body:
```
let a = [1, 2, 3]
_.remove(a)
console.log(a) // [ ]
```

the problem case is when second parameter is provided, but is `undefined` or `null`. Consider 

```
let a = [1, 2, 3]
let badElement = getBadElement()
_(a).remove(badElement)
```

if `badElement` may or may not exists - you need to check it for `!= null` before remove

I propose to change current behavior and remove nothing when second parameter is `undefined` because while first example with single argument just don't make any sense to be written, second is an unpleasant surprise when you ask method to remove `undefined` and it removes just all. But if you think it's ok - at list it should be described in the docs

Thanks

title: (Docs) Safari 9.0.2 won't scroll the side-nav-bar sometimes
body:
So the left sidebar will stopp scrolling after the right side was scrolled down. Somehow only the main content will scroll after that, even when hovering the sidebar. The sidebar will only start scrolling again after scrolling the main content to the top. 

Chrome does not have this issue. I noticed that chrome will always show the scrollbars on both, while Safari hides them. Maybe there is a css fix...

title: toArray documentation possibly misleading
body:
https://lodash.com/docs#toArray

It says `Converts value to an array.`
However `_.toArray(1)` does return `[]`, so it only works with objects, arguments, array, string. Not with any type of value.
It depends how you read `convert value to array` so i would expect `_.toArray(1) => [1]`
So clearer documentation would be nice :)

Relates to #953

title: add test case for `sortBy` with property syntax and context
body: I was recently bit by the regression mentioned in #1530 where using `_.sortBy` with a property shorthand and a supplied context stopped working. The bug has since been fixed, but this PR adds a test case to help discover future regressions.

title: Feature request: function to coerce strings to other primitive types
body:
Hi,

Is there a method in lodash to convert strings to number/boolean?
something like this:

```
function parse(val) {
  if (val === 'true') return true
  if (val === 'false') return false
  if (! Number.isNaN(+val)) return +val
  else return val
}
```

Do you think it makes sense to add something like this?
(use case is eg. parsing cookie values, parsing input values)

title: The opposite of _.where? _.exclude?
Async support in ```_.template(...)```
body:
Hi there,

I'm currently looking at taking lodash in a small little utility that I'm working (currently I'm using underscore). Specifically I'm looking at using the `template(...)` function. The syntax of the templates that I use is as follows (where the code evaluated between brackets is the executable code):

```
"[function1()]blah[function2()]blah[function3()]"
```

That works fine, but I run into trouble when some of the functions need to execute code asynchronously, for example, lets say that functions 1 & 2 simply return a string based on computations that can be done locally, but function 3 needs to make a call to a REST API. At the moment I would need to use a library such as sync-request which spins of a child process.

I was thinking however that it would be awesome if lodash could look at the values of the objects being returned from the functions it is calling and determine whether it looks like a Promise, then setup a promise that would them be returned from the template function.

Perhaps it would be better to have a different function for a Promise aware version of `template(...)``.

Anyway - thought I would start the conversation here just to see what people think.

title: _.set treats numbers as arrays
body:
tl;dr 
"a[10].b" is interpreted the same as "a.10.b"

I am trying to create a deep path where one of the properties is a number. When I put the number as part of the path it creates an array instead of creating a property.
I debugged _.set very superficially and saw that both the expression "a[10].b" and "a.10.b" are broken into the same three pieces ["a","10","b"] and therefore have the same meaning.

Is this an issue or the intended behavior? 
If this is the intended behavior then what do I need to write to create an object with a number property?

title: Deep Cloning sparse array inserts spurious 'undefined' values
body:
Was surprised to find that a `_.cloneDeep` call on a sparse array causes `undefined` values to be inserted, instead of leaving unassigned numerical indexes. Below is a node REPL session which shows the problem. 

Note the difference between `JSON.stringify` of the original sparse array in which numbers are not assigned, and of the cloned sparse array in which numbers are assigned with the value 'undefined'. 

``` js
> var arr = []
undefined
> arr[2]="val"
'val'
> arr
[ , , 'val' ]
> arrClone = lodash.cloneDeep(arr)
[ undefined, undefined, 'val' ]
```

This variation between items and their clones has already created some gnarly bugs from comparisons generated according to the JSON patch IETF RFC 6902. In particular the comparison algorithms of fast-json-patch generates a 'remove' changeset between a previously snapshotted clone (with its undefined values) and the original (which has no undefined values at the same relative paths).

title: Chain interruption
body:
I have a lodash chain which looks something like this:

``` js
chain(req.headers.cookie)
.thru(parseCookie)
.property(stateCookie)
.thru(JSON.parse) 
```

At a couple of points, the value might be `undefined` or another falsey value. Is there a way to interrupt chain execution when there is a falsey value and just return that falsey value?

question: how to chain properly with modularized build?
body:
``` shell
nesh> var chain = require('lodash/chain/chain');
nesh> chain(['foo']).reject('foo').value()
TypeError: chain(...).reject is not a function
```

Use case:  instead of `require('lodash')` everywhere, I'm attempting to keep a browserified build of my app lean.  This was working fine until I wanted to chain methods.  

I was hoping to avoid a custom build this way, but that may be what needs to happen.

title: Update indexOf signature documentation
body:
First parameter does not need to be an array. It can be an instance of any itterable object.

This is causing some ambiguity, e.g. people think that `_.indexOf` cannot be used with a string (see https://github.com/wix/eslint-plugin-lodash3/issues/11#issuecomment-165751936).

title: `reduce` fails on objects with "length" key
body:
When an object with the key `"length"` is passed as the collection to reduce, reduce fails.
Ex:

```
reduce = require("lodash").reduce;
reduce({ foo: 'bar', length: 12 }, function (res, val, key) {
  res[key] = val;
  return res;
}, {})
```

results in:

```
{ '0': undefined,
  '1': undefined,
  '2': undefined,
  '3': undefined,
  '4': undefined,
  '5': undefined,
  '6': undefined,
  '7': undefined,
  '8': undefined,
  '9': undefined,
  '10': undefined,
  '11': undefined }
```

Perhaps it gets interpreted as an array? However, `isArray` does the right thing, i.e. :

```
> require('lodash').isArray({length:12})
false
```

title: ES6 and FP in Lodash 4
body:
I keep seeing this shim referenced in discussions about bringing FP to Lodash 4:

``` js
require('lodash/fp')()
```

I assume that in ES6, this would have to look something like:

``` js
import initFp from 'lodash/fp'
import {some, zip} from 'lodash'

initFp()
zip(...)
```

Perhaps I'm missing something, but this doesn't seem very idiomatic to me.
- Is that idea that this should be called once at the top of my project's main entry point(s)? If so, do I also need to include it at the top of all of my tests, assuming they don't import from the main entry?
- Either way, doesn't this add a fair bit of overhead on app init?
- What is the compatibility here with the new Lodash ES build? I'd hate to lose tree-shaking just because I want FP.

What I seem to want is an interface more like the one that exists for lodash-fp:

``` js
import {some, zip} from 'lodash/fp'

zip(...)
```

What are your thoughts on this?

Thanks for your work on Lodash!

title: _.max bug?
_(obj).omit() call with wrapped object
body:
Works fine:

``` javascript
var obj = {foo: 'foo', bar:'bar', zzz: 'zzz'};
_.omit(obj,'bar') // => {foo: "foo", zzz: "zzz"}
```

But these two don't:

``` javascript
_(obj).omit('bar');
_.chain(obj).omit('bar')
```

There is obviously expected the obj with the 'foo' and 'zzz'  properties are not omitted
but in the both calls the same lodash wrapper is returned. 
Second case also has a  __chain__ property's value assigned to the true,
while of the first case it is not. Docs say the omit() is chainable.
Don't know exactly bug :bug: or feature. Help is needed.:)

Lodash version 3.10.1
Tested in Chrome 48.0.2564.22 dev-m (64-bit)

title: Documentation for _.get
body:
Given this:

`var foo = [123, 456];
var bar = _.get(foo, 0);`

bar is now `123`

However, a JavaScript IDE rightly complains as path of `0` is not an Array or a string.  Should the documentation be updated for _.get path (Array|string|int)?

Current documentation for _.get
`path (Array|string): The path of the property to get.`

title: issue/bug with partial
body:
I'm not sure if this is a bug or I'm doing something weird, but running below in the NodeJS (v0.12.0) prompt shows

``` js
['1', '2', '3', '4', '5', '7'].every(function(d) {return lodash.contains('712345', d);})
// => true

['1', '2', '3', '4', '5', '7'].every(lodash.partial(lodash.contains, '712345'))
// => false
```

Why is the behavior different?

title: Undeprecate older lodash versions on npm
body:
The issue https://github.com/npm/npmlog/issues/25 was closed as won't fix and breaks Windows environments.  The deprecation command can be undone in npm so I think it should be until Windows or npm changes their behavior.

Ref https://github.com/gulpjs/glob-watcher/issues/23
Ref https://github.com/shama/gaze/issues/207
Ref https://github.com/cowboy/node-globule/pull/22

None of which will be fixed anytime soon and it's actually lodash that broke Windows users.

title: _.set creates arrays when sees integres in paths (and this weird behaviour isn't documented)
New function: scan
Support for ECMA2015 classes in _functions()
_.include finds numbers in strings
body:
`_.include('12345', 3)` returns true, whereas http://ecma-international.org/ecma-262/6.0/#sec-samevaluezero states that types are included in matching elements.

However, `_.include(_.toArray('12345'), 3)` returns false, as expected.

Is that desired behavior?

title: Feature suggestion: asymmetric size for _.chunk
body:
Please consider the following case: I'm willing to chunk an array of 100 elements, but I want each element to be twice as big as the previous one so that after chunking:
- the first one has 5 elements
- the second one has 10
- the third+ ones have 20 each

Now `_.chunk` only allows to split evenly. Whet if it allowed to split unevenly? I don't yet know how to express the rule in a flexible way (maybe a numerical sequence?) but it looks to me like a nice improvement to what `_.chunk` can do now.

Real life example:
I'm batching elements of infinite scroll list. I want first chunk to be small, next one to be bigger and so on (with some limit off course)

title: The migration docs should mention the difference between which properties lodash's and Underscore's _.clone method copies
body:
A colleague of mine just got bitten by a difference between lodash's `_.clone` and Underscore's `_.clone` that isn't mentioned at https://github.com/lodash/lodash/wiki/Migrating

He was using `_.clone` on an [Immutable JS](https://facebook.github.io/immutable-js/) Map object. (Yes, this was probably an entirely wrong thing to do in the first place.) With Underscore, this produced an object that retained all the methods of the original object. After swapping to Lodash, it produces an object without any Immutable JS methods.

While our particular use case was admittedly unique, there are probably more reasonable situations in which people could be bitten by the same behaviour difference.

I haven't looked at the code, but I'd guess that Underscore is copying all enumerable properties whereas lodash is copying all properties that are direct properties of the object and not of its prototype?

title: npm WARN deprecated lodash@ warning is scary
body:
Hey @jdalton! getting a lot of these recently:

"I don't know what's up with the lodash error..." regarding the lodash deprecation warnings.

We avoided using this npm feature in some grunt plugins because it confuses plugin users. It is a good thing to communicate to package maintainers, but not users.

Just something to reconsider doing in the future. I think this mostly affects developers who do not deal with node / npm much.

title: People forget what they already have. which is much faster and beautiful.

```
var users = [{ id: 1, online: true }, { id: 2, online: false }];
_.where(users, 'online');
```

Now in 3.x it's not working. I haven't find any clue in docs or changelog.

Thank you.

title: NaN as number
body:
Hello, I found something odd here.

Imagine the following code:

``` javascript
parseInt ({}, 10);
```

This should return _NaN_ 'cause an _object_ can't turn in a _number_.

But if _NaN_ is _Not-A-Number_, although the type of _NaN_ is _number_ (sic), I guess `_.isNumber(NaN)`  should be false.

Why? When normally uses `_.isNumber` is wanted to know if I really have a number to calculate, to iterate, anyway... not?

title: chore(package): update webpack to version 1.12.9
body: http://greenkeeper.io/

title: _.invoke change.
body:
I'd like to bring up changing `_.invoke` to an Object method. In master I've exposed `_.invokePath`.
I'd like `_.invokePath` to be named `_.invoke` and the old `_.invoke` renamed to `_.mapInvoke`. 

I'm interested in feedback, specifically @jridgewell and @megawac, as you all contribute to Backbone which would need updating if the rename was to happen.

title: Ability to use unended chain
body:
Since v3 LoDash has lazy evaluations, and it is very cool. My approach is to extent it's usage without breaking anything. 
Consider

```
let a = [1, 2, 3]
let b = [2, 3, 4]
```

Point is that now there is a sense of ending chain only on function call, for example like

```
_(a).intercept(b)
```

which can be used somewhere else, or evaluated with `.value()`.
But ending chain sequence on function without calling it could also have sense

```
let isInAAndB = _(a).intercept(b).includes
```

In current realization this will produce an absolutely useless function (it will even throw on call).

Approach is to add a function (only for chain) that will bind function it's invoked on on current chain. Like

```
let isInAAndB = _(a).intercept(b).includes.build()
```

Name `build` is just an example - definitely some one may came up with something better.

In theory each function in chain could be a method and work like this by default, but as far as I can imagine it may be a performance hit, this is why I suggest a separate function. If I'm wrong and it is not a performance hit - it definitely should just be a default behavior.

title: Partials, partials everywhere
body:
When used with promises, streams and nested structures, `_.partial` is a common and very useful tool but it often piles up with other functions and decreases readability.

Scala short syntax for anonymous functions suggests a way to simplify things a bit: `list.map(_*2)`. The idea is to return partial function whenever `_` is provided as an argument. Some examples:

``` javascript
// from this:
_.map(objects, _.partial(_.set, _, 'index', _))
// to this:
_.map(objects, _.set(_, 'index', _))


// from this:
getUsers()
    .then(users =>
        _.map(users, _.partial(_.omit, _, ['password', 'salt', 'email']))
// to this:
getUsers().then(_.map(_, _.omit(_, ['password', 'salt', 'email'])))
```

This is a breaking and maybe controversial change, and I'm curious if you would consider implementing or at least discussing it.

title: lt, lte, gt, gte, add and other 'binary' functions with single argument
body:
For now there is no sense in functions that represents binary operation to be called with single argument. My proposal is to make them return a function in such case. It is almost like make them auto curry but in this case we should bind not first, but second parameter. So

```
let gt3 = _.gt(3)
```

Would be the same as

```
let gt3 = _.partial(_.gt, _, 3)
```

so it could be used like

```
let a = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
_.filter(a, _.gt(3)) // [4, 5]
_.map(a, _.add(3)) // [4, 5, 6, 7, 8]
```

title: In version "3.10.1" function _.round gives wrong result
body: `_.round(1.005, 2)` gives `1`, while must be `1.01`.

title: chore(package): update jscs to version 2.6.0
body: http://greenkeeper.io/

title: Does isEqual support FormData?
body:
First up, thank you for maintaining such a powerful/ valuable piece of software. Without all your time we would each spend countless time re-inventing the wheel.

---

I'm new to lodash and mostly want to be educated on how isEqual works/or doesn't with FormData. My limited understanding is that isEqual offers a "deep" equality check. This works great for Array when I expect 2 diff Arrays to match (when the primitive values they contain are equivalent). When I do something similar w/ FormData it seems I get false. Is this intentional? If yes, do you suggest (or have) another api I could use to assert equality?

It does appear that calling $(mockData).serializeArray(); will produce something isEqual can compare against (like Array). Is it possible you would accept a PR to improve isEqual (to add support for FormData)?

Thanks again for helping provide such a great open source library/ecosystem!

![screen shot 2015-11-19 at 11 51 42 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/147411/11279146/74eaf350-8eb4-11e5-87e4-fa6608ac956a.png)

title: Add a string function to remove double spaces
body:
This is a fairly common requirement.

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/3286874/remove-all-multiple-spaces-in-javascript-and-replace-with-single-space

It is as simple as `input.replace(/\s\s+/g, '')`, but:
- as evident in Stack Overflow, developers come up with inventive (and not necessarily good) ways to do it.
- no one likes to read regex written by other developers, regardless of how simple it is.

A simple `_.despace` function would be convenient.

title: New Function: _.splice for Object
Compounder functions should not break apart [0-9][a-z]
body: Currently, passing isoCode2b or iso_code_2b to .snakeCase() will return iso_code_2_b. Additionally, iso_code_2b passed to .camelCase() gives isoCode2B, though I would expect isoCode2b. In general, this behavior seems a more consistent means of breaking apart "words", given that no uppercase follows.
